frame.name: Actually_occurring_entity
frame.definition:
<def-root>Against the background of a contextually salient non-real world, for instance a hypothetical, imagined, simulated, expected, projected, or dream world, an <fen>Instance</fen> of a <fen>Type</fen> encountered in a relation or event in the real world is presented as being different from the instance found in the non-real world. Of course, the real-world <fen>Instance</fen> of the expected <fen>Type</fen> may also be presented as not occurring, as in the last example below.
<ex><t>Actual</t> <fex name="Type">results</fex> may vary.</ex> <ex><fex name="ins">ACTUAL results</fex> may vary.</ex>
<ex>Also present is the <t>actual</t> <fex name="Type">policeman</fex>, now 20 years older and helping to cast and prepare the young actor who'll be portraying him onscreen.</ex> <ex>Also present is <fex name="ins">the ACTUAL policeman</fex>, now 20 years older and helping to cast and prepare the young actor who'll be portraying him onscreen.</ex>
<ex>Of course, an <t>actual</t> <fex name="Type">car</fex> with all these capabilities simply did not exist.</ex> <ex>Of course, <fex name="ins">an ACTUAL car</fex> with all these capabilities simply did not exist.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Instance
FE.definition:
<def-root>The real-world individual--a concrete or abstract thing or an event--which differs from its counterpart in a discourse-salient non-real world.
<ex>In May of 1994, FBI agents working for Mr. Fiske interviewed Mrs. Foster, showed her <fex name="ins">an ACTUAL gun</fex>, not a photo, and asked her if she could identify the gun.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Type
FE.definition:
<def-root>A kind of entity, instances of which are expected to occur in both the real and the non-real world.
<ex>His <t>actual</t> <fex name="Type">name</fex> was Nabu-Kudurri-Usur.</ex></def-root>
